lines.text:
[the professor is putting money on a footrace between Flash and Johnny]
That there's gold!
My yearly stipend as a teacher. A molder of young minds.
Fifty dollars!
It's not much, but neither are the minds I mold.
That 4th of July race... what happens when you win?
Well, according to a friend of mine, if I win, a beautiful girl will place a garland of oak leaves on my sun-colored locks.
I'd like to be that girl.
Maybe it can be arranged?
Oh, it can be arranged, all right. *I'll* arrange it.

[On the riverboat with Susanna, visiting the South for the first time]
You were right, Mrs. Shawnessy, I like your river. I really do. It even smells good.
I knew that you'd understand it. Which is more than most Yankees do. Now, that's something I don't understand. 'Cause all you have to do is go South once and you LOVE it!
Well, to us Yankees, the South is not too easy to understand... You ever read "Uncle Tom's Cabin"?

[Shocked]
"Uncle Tom's Cabin"? Phoo... I haven't married an abolitionist, have I?
That is the skeleton in my closet.
Now, you mustn't joke about it.

[Arranging a vast collection of dolls on her bed]
Anyway, there's worse things than being an abolitionist.
Like what?
Like having Negro blood in you. Isn't it funny? Just one little teeny drop and a person's all Negro. A person can't always tell, either.
War is the most monstrous of man's illusions. Any idea worth anything is worth not fighting for.

[to the photographer, who has just taken the graduating class portrait]
Mr. Sterling, you have made us immortal.
"Some do it chew, and some do it smoke, while some it up their noses do poke."
I do all three at the same time.
Greatness? Ha! If that great philosopher, Socrates, were living today, he'd be reduced to sitting on a cracker barrel, chewing tobacco. That's what America does for greatness.

[to Flash, who is drinking beer in public]
Flash Perkins, don't you know that your body is the temple of the spirit, and you defile and pollute it with that Devil's brew you have there?

[Nonchalantly]
Why, if you say so, pappy...
Why don't you come 'round to our next temperance rally. Come 'round and take the Total Abstinence Pledge.
Why, pappy, I'll take that pledge right now.
Orville, we want men to take that pledge only when they're sober.
But if they're sober, what's the point in havin' them take the pledge?
[Everybody laughs]

[Referring to the fact that Mr. Gray, an old man, has managed to marry Lydia, a beautiful young woman]
How in the entire realm of plausibility did that chilly January win such a blithesome May?

[On the back of the train, leaving town in a hurry]
Goodbye, dear friend. Remember me as a man who loves Raintree County, but just happens to loathe most of the people in it.
Johnny, I had to come back. I'm going to have a baby.
We in the South dream of a great republic on the soil of America. Within its pillared homes dwell the most beautiful women.

[Chuckling]
Oh, Sam, you are wonderful. You shovel that stuff with a golden pitchfork!
Cousin Sam, John doesn't like slavery.
Does John like the "wage slavery" of the North?

[People are gathering in the town center]
What's going on here?
You haven't heard? They've attacked Fort Sumter. It means war sure as anything.
I'm not so sure. Now, say what you will, Americans will never fight each other. We'll settle our difficulties peacefully.

[to John and Flash, sitting in the woods not far from Confederate lines]
Comrades in arms, a toast. To all the men who go out and die, and merely because they have the rotten luck to be born one side or another of a mountain or a creek...

[Takes a swig]
And here's to sleep...
a place called Hell.

[Narrating]
May the 16th, 1864. Resaca, Georgia. Another day of dramatic corpse-making.
the home-grown tomatoes are always best.
My students seem to enjoy creepin' up on me.
They're all in love with you.
Teachers get fallen in love with. It's an occupational hazard.
